issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify a method addGuestStudents(int) (a single int parameter). The solution repository implements addGuestStudents(int). However the template repository declares addGuestStudents with a different signature: addGuestStudents(int, boolean). This parameter mismatch is structural (not an empty stub) and will confuse students: they will implement the single-argument method as instructed, but the template already contains a two-argument method that does not match the specification or the solution, causing compilation/signature conflicts or test failures.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template method signature match the specification and the solution by changing the template declaration to: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { /* TODO */ }. Alternatively, if the two-parameter signature was intentional, update the problem statement and solution (UML and text) to describe addGuestStudents(int, boolean) and explain the purpose of the boolean parameter. Prefer changing the template to the single-arg signature to preserve the exercise intent and avoid student confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement and solution specify a method addGuestStudents(int) (single int parameter), but the template code provides a stub with a different signature: addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput). This signature mismatch (extra boolean parameter in the template) creates a direct mapping/confusion for students: they will expect to implement or call a single-argument method as described in the UML and tests, but the provided template requires two arguments. This can cause compilation/test failures and unnecessary cognitive load while students try to reconcile the differing method signatures.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template method signature with the problem statement and solution. Change the template stub to: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { /* ... */ } and remove the boolean parameter. Implement validation internally if needed, or update the problem statement and solution if a boolean flag is intentionally required.
